definition: A playful or silly act (usually in the plural ‘antics’); bizarre or comic in appearance or behaviour.
examples: The puppy’s antics made everyone laugh. (noun, usually plural)
He wore an antic hat to the party. (adjective)

extra.memory_tip: Think ‘antics’ = funny actions; ‘antic’ = odd or comic.

definition: Clothing; to dress someone in particular clothes (formal).
examples: Formal attire is required for the ceremony. (noun)
They were attired in bright costumes. (verb)

definition: To charm and hold someone’s attention completely.
examples: The storyteller captivated the audience.
Bright colours captivate young children.

extra.memory_tip: CaptiVATE = make them a captive with interest.

definition: Skilful and quick in movement or action.
examples: With deft hands, she folded the paper crane.
The chef made a deft slice.

extra.memory_tip: Deft = deftly done, no effort seen.

definition: Working hard and carefully; showing steady effort.
examples: Her diligent study led to top marks.
He is diligent about practising daily.

extra.memory_tip: Diligent = do it again and again, well.

definition: When one body blocks the light of another; to make something seem less important or bright by comparison.
examples: We watched the lunar eclipse. (noun)
Her performance eclipsed all others. (verb)

definition: To develop gradually; to change over time.
examples: Languages evolve as people use them.
The plan evolved after feedback.

definition: Existing from birth; natural, not learned.
examples: She has an innate sense of rhythm.
Curiosity is often innate in children.

definition: To write or carve words or symbols on something.
examples: They inscribed her name on the trophy.
A date was inscribed on the stone.

definition: The position in which someone holds their body; to adopt a particular position or attitude.
examples: Good posture helps your back. (noun)
He postured as a neutral observer. (verb)

definition: A covering, often for a body; to cover or hide from view.
examples: Fog was a shroud over the harbour. (noun)
Mist shrouded the hills. (verb)

definition: To hold back or stop something; to make it hard to breathe.
examples: Please don’t stifle questions in class.
The heat was stifling in the tent.

extra.memory_tip: Stifle = stifle a sniffle or a spark.

definition: Not certain or fixed; done carefully and without confidence.
examples: We made a tentative plan for Friday.
She gave a tentative smile.

extra.memory_tip: Tentative = like a tent—temporary and adjustable.

definition: Calm and peaceful; free from noise or worry.
examples: We paddled across a tranquil lake.
The garden felt tranquil at dusk.

definition: Able to do many different things well; having many uses.
examples: It’s a versatile tool for camping.
She is a versatile actor who plays comic and serious roles.
